generation: Another week just flew by. I drove past the new house yesterday, and the front window was covered in boxes. We may get the keys at closing—I'm so excited! If all goes well this week, we’ll be set for closing a week from Wednesday. I was up until after 3:00 AM last night watching movies with Bethany. There’s been a lot of movie-watching around here lately. Here’s my rundown: last night we watched *Thirteen*, a film every mother of a teen should see. It was better than I expected. Then we watched *Gigli*—yeah, it was just as bad as the media claimed, but we had to see for ourselves.

Summer TV used to be a dead zone full of repeats or something. But now there are two great new shows on, and I’ve been watching both religiously for the past week. *Blow Out*—the gayest concept ever that seemingly has zero gay people in sight. Hairstylist Jonathan Antin wants to build a second location for his incredibly popular West Hollywood salon, this time in Beverly Hills. Normally no one would care, certainly not me, but as I was flipping through the channels, I caught a glimpse of Jonathan—equally narcissistic and dull—looking at an empty space on Rodeo Dr., declaring (in a public voice), 'I am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world!' And I was hooked. Not since Rocco have I found such a moron compelling to watch."

What a week... My right shoulder has tendinitis. It's right under my shoulder blade. So, when I move my arm too much, especially while using a mouse on a computer... It kills me. I can't move it much now because I was on a spree updating my website and working on other online tasks. I can barely muster the strength to draw anything. Lack of sleep adds to my pain. I'm not too happy right now, but I'll get better. My mom's surgery went okay. Her eyesight has improved slightly. She can see fuzzy shapes and distinguish colors. Other than that, she's still blind as all sin. Hopefully she'll fully regain her vision soon.

Kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how quickly the simplest things can become a freaking ordeal. I also learned how remarkably sweet strangers can be for no reason other than because they feel like being kind. Trust me. It wasn’t like they were trying to get into my pants or anything. I had kid drool all over me and was wearing my 'wash-day' outfit... Also, I’m not entirely sure I’ll ever bathe again, so it’s not like there was even an olfactory incentive there! I’m doing two things right now: composing a post and watching the collected No Doubt videos. I’m doing both of these while sitting at my desk in my room."

Last night in class, we discussed that week’s assigned reading, *Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World*, by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores “implacement” while the second examines “displacement.” In the opening chapter, Casey argues that our contemporary world and culture prioritize time as the organizing force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He contends that centering culture around place fosters a more grounded community. (This is a rough summary—just in case my professor or classmates happen to read this post.) So far, this book is the first reading that has truly gripped me.

Fall 1974: I was attempting for what felt like the thirteenth time to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then—nor am I now—a math person. I hate math. I am math-phobic. You get the picture. As I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I set down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies, and just as I found a glimmer of understanding buried in my subconscious, the doorbell rang again. Bam—just like that, my breakthrough vanished. I went to the door, and once again, no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs: an uninvited practical joker."

GOP gets scolded over recruitment. Naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville are to be relocated after complaints that GOP activists registered new citizens as Republicans. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy, the citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville seemed to proceed as usual, with a crowd of nearly 200 people becoming new Americans. Just before the new citizens left the June 29 event, an immigration official overseeing the swearing-in urged them to visit a voter registration table—a common sight at such ceremonies. However, this table was unusual: those distributing forms were Republican volunteers, and the party affiliation box had been pre-checked to enroll all new voters as GOP members. The situation raised suspicions for Linda Cross, who was there to witness her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

Halloween writer Debra Hill dies. Screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, best known for her work on the 1970s horror classic *Halloween*, has died in Los Angeles at age 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it earned over $60 million (£31.3m) worldwide—a record for independent films at the time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on *Escape from New York* and *The Fog*. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and rose through the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before partnering with Carpenter. She was widely regarded as a pioneering woman in film, taking on roles in the 70s that were typically dominated by men.

For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/2$ white noise. In comparison, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states requires only two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/3$ white noise.

Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution for an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, characterized by a distinct multipolar structure determined solely by its mass and spin. We develop a general method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a broad family of horizonless microstate geometries. These can violate the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric and exhibit a far richer multipolar structure, offering a pathway to phenomenologically constrain fuzzball models. We find numerical evidence that all multipole moments are typically larger (in absolute value) than those of a Kerr black hole with identical mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates can only impose weak constraints on fuzzballs, whereas future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the LISA mission will enhance these bounds significantly."

Density-based clustering relies on the idea of linking groups to specific features of the probability distribution underlying the data. The nonparametric formulation of this approach, known as modal clustering, establishes a correspondence between the groups and the domains of attraction of the density modes. Operationally, a nonparametric density estimate is required, and a proper selection of the smoothing parameter, governing the shape of the density and thus the modal structure, is crucial to identify the final partition. In this work, we address the issue of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective.

The weak gravity conjecture (WGC) requires the existence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. Avoiding this contradiction leads to a nonperturbative version of the WGC, which reduces to the usual statement at weak coupling. The argument is general and does not rely on supersymmetry or a specific UV completion, assuming only the validity of Einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

We introduce a novel Skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, based on the concept of hidden local symmetry. The associated charge is equivalent to the Skyrmion charge for any smooth configuration. Moreover, there exist singular configurations that can be identified as \( n_f=1 \) baryons charged under the new symmetry. Under this identification, the vector mesons act as the Chern-Simons vector fields residing on the quantum Hall droplet that forms the \( n_f=1 \) baryon. We propose that this current represents the correct effective expression for the baryon current at low energies. This proposal provides a unified description for the two types of baryons and enables them to transform continuously into one another naturally. Furthermore, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be interpreted as a consequence of Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions offers a fascinating way to merge anomalous Hall and Josephson physics in a single device. We extend the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, originally developed to quantify conventional (tunneling) Josephson currents, to assess the transverse current components and show that their amplitudes are highly tunable via spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. As a distinct spectroscopic signature of Josephson junctions, well-localized subgap bound states form near the interface.

Low-symmetry 2D materials—such as ReS$_2$ and ReSe$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, borophene, among others—exhibit more complex atomistic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. Weight pruning has been widely acknowledged as a straightforward and effective method to eliminate redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), thereby achieving acceleration on various platforms. However, most pruning techniques are essentially trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity, leading to impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration performance. To address this problem, we introduce a new sparsity dimension—pattern-based sparsity—which comprises pattern and connectivity sparsity, achieving both high accuracy and hardware efficiency. With carefully designed patterns, our proposed pruning method consistently enhances accuracy and improves feature extraction across various DNN architectures and datasets. Additionally, our pattern-aware pruning framework simultaneously performs pattern library extraction, pattern selection, and connectivity pruning alongside weight training. Our approach to pattern-based sparsity naturally integrates with compiler optimizations for highly efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.
